Any extracellular nanobot-linked biomolecule could be removed or inhibited via a separate pathway, and then a magnetic field could be applied to effect conformational change in the intracellular 'nanobot-linked biomolecules'. Back in the late 1980's early 1990's we did the exact opposite with thin film UV curing resins, We used the UV Glue supplied by RadioSpares, and diluted it with various test solvents. The concept that worked quite well was intended for 'underglaze' porcelain pottery decoration. The cured area was where a dusting of fine pigmented underglaze powder stuck to the sticky uncured areas. Multiple layers of different colour pigment could be applied. One application that we thought might be appropriate was the restoration of valuable pottery that had been broken, but there were missing parts. The exact shade of porcelain could be selected and machined into a very close match, a pattern would often be a repeat. so with computer graphics a very close match of the pattern could be achieved. A Priceless heirloom could theoretically be repaired sufficiently well to appear undamaged to the naked eye. but clearly not under a microscope.

I don't feel like the professor directly answered the question about magnetics supplanting the idea of nanorobotics. I'd say no, because heretofore concepts of nanorobotics have not adequately addressed the issue of power, so on that point, there's no prior art to supplant. (Not saying there aren't other possible solutions, just that none have significant precedence, i.e. they haven't delivered results yet.) The professor's answer smentioned considering the magnetic device as the gripper portion of a robotic arm, with all the equipment needed to generate and control the required magnetic fields being like the rest of the arm. It seems likely that any other means of powering and controlling nanaoscale manipulators will also include such external support, and the sci-fi notion of completely independent and autonomous nanobots is a far off reality.
